Title: Proving that $\gcd(2^m - 1, 2^n - 1) = 2^{\gcd(m,n )} - 1$
Content: Somewhere on Stack Exchange I saw the equation $$\gcd(2^m-1,2^n-1)=2^{\gcd(m,n)}-1.$$ I had never seen this before, so I started trying to prove it. Without success... Can anyone explain me (so actually prove) why this equation is true? And can we say the same when replacing the '$2$' by any integer number '$a$'?
AcceptedAnswer: In general, if $p=\gcd(m,n)$ then $p=mx+ny$ for some integers $x,y$. Now, if $d = \gcd(2^m-1,2^n-1)$ then $2^m \equiv 1 \pmod d$ and $2^n \equiv 1\pmod d$ so $$2^p = 2^{mx+ny} = (2^m)^x(2^n)^y \equiv 1 \pmod d$$ So $d\mid 2^p-1$. On the other hand, if $p\mid m$ then $2^p-1\mid 2^m-1$ so $2^p-1$ is a common factor. And yes, you can replace $2$ with any $a$.
